"And China is here. USA is here. In a few years? They age even farther ahead."
*he used his hands to gesture. Idk what is being measured
"But I just saw the election as two bad candidates and some of that novelty for Trump has started to wear off."
"But, you know, I recently got injured and now it's extra difficult for me to get back in Border Patrol and I don't think Trump will help."
"I'm in law enforcement with Border Patrol and me and my buddies were excited for the things Trump was gonna do for us."
"I don't really like anything I have seen from him so far though. I don't think he gives a shit what America wants, ya know. *sigh*"
"With Hillary, I just felt like it was going to be all the same, struggling economy, always #2 to China, & Trump maybe could be new track."

How much shelter & support would you provide as Trump & Co. deploy "deportation squads" and "Muslim registries?"
Start building courage now
Are #WomensMarch participants willing to resist insofar as that may mean disruption, financial support, and civil disobedience of law?
There isn't a pink hat on any of these issues, but they impact particular women in particular ways.
And what about universal pre-k, labor unions, public schools, mass incarceration, and higher minimum wages?
What will you do for black women who aren't afforded police protection or whose housing rights are denied?
By the time awful shit is obvious, mad people will already have been affected.
"I'll call my rep," is one thing, but there is probably so much more and attempts to connect w/ & support those resources should start now
It's one thing to yell slogans at buildings, but organizing and resisting gets many fewer "likes" and is often hard and essential work
.@aurabogado's question "what would you do if DACA is eliminated?" is so salient and should be considered if u were at #WomensMarch
